block.p: Introduced on Thursday: Callaway C16 Cabrio
Is it real? This superswift convertible, based on the Corvette C6, is available in minute quantities, manufactured in California. Or Connecticut. Or Germany.
What's the point? To provide an alternative for people who feel a 505-horsepower Corvette Z06 is just too darned slow.
What they said: "There's a niche that believes that too much is never enough," said Mike Vendetto, Callaway spokesman. "We hope to fit that piece of the puzzle."
What they didn't say: Who exactly is paying $128,765 or tens of thousands more with optional equipment for what is essentially a rebodied Corvette with lots more power.

What makes it tick? There's no doubt the Callaway is a world-class scorcher, running from 0 to 60 miles an hour in 3.3 seconds, covering the quarter-mile in 10.9 seconds. (That's for the highest-powered version.) A supercharged, 6.0-liter 'Vette V-8 delivers either 560 or an optional 616 horsepower.
How much, how soon? Order one today the company says it's sold five already and you'll wait roughly 10 to 12 weeks for delivery.

How's it look? Like the Corvette's sophisticated European cousin, especially the Ferrari-like snout and eggcrate grille. Spendthrift buyers may as well drop another 23 grand for the special German leather interior, available in virtually any color.
